names.pharmaceuticalLatin: Radix Glycyrrhizae Radix Glycyrrhizae Preparata (Zhi Gan Cao)

action.primary: Tonifies the Spleen and augments Qi

indications: Spleen Qi Deficiency with shortness of breath, lassitude and loose stools
Qi and Blood Deficiency with an irregular pulse and/or palpitations
Heart Qi Deficiency or Heart Yang Deficiency

action.primary: Moistens the Lungs, resolves Phlegm and stops coughing

indications: Painful muscle spasms of the abdomen and legs

action.primary: Clears Heat and relieves Fire toxicity

indications: Raw for Toxic Heat with sore throat or carbuncles and sores (Chuang Yung)

action.primary: Moderates and harmonizes the harsh properties of other herbs and guides the herbs to all twelve channels

contraindications: Contraindicated in those with Excess Dampness with nausea, vomiting and abdominal fullness.
Contraindicated in those who frequently drink wine.
Contraindicated in those who have hypertension, edema, hyperglycemic conditions, osteoporosis and general Excess secretions.
Large doses (over 35 gm during a one week period) can create a sodium/potassium imbalance in the blood creating edema and heart palpitations.
incompatibilities: Incompatible with Flos Genkwa #{YuanHua} Yuan Hua.
Incompatible with Rx. Euphorbiae seu Knoxiae #{HongJingDaJi} Jing Da Ji.
Incompatible with Sargassum #{HaiZao} Hai Zao (it is frequently used with this herb).
Incompatible with Rx. Kansui #{GanSui} Gan Sui
interactions: This herb may alter the therapeutic effects of corticosteroids such as cortisone, prednisone (Orasone), dexamethasone (Decadron), hydrocortisone (Cortef) and methoprednisolone (Medrol).
Use with caution with cardioglycosides such as digoxin (Lanoxin).
This herb speeds the metabolism of drugs such as chloral hydrate, urethane, cocaine, picrotoxin, caffeine, pilocarpine, nicotine, and barbiturates and treats overdose of these agents.

useCases: Anorexia, fatigue and loose stools due to Spleen Deficiency.
Strengthens the Spleen and augments Qi.
Palpitations due to Heart Qi Deficiency.
Heart Qi and Blood Deficiency with an irregular heart beat and palpitations.
Coughing or wheezing due to Wind-Cold Attacks the Lungs.
Pain and swelling of the throat.
Wind-Heat Invading the Lungs.
Coughing due to Lung Heat.
Moderates spasms and alleviates pain, for painful spasms of the leg or abdomen.
Abdominal pain and dysenteric diarrhea from Damp-Heat.
Hypochondriac pain due to Liver Qi Stagnation.
Peptic ulcer pain.
Gastric discomfort with hyperacidity.
Epigastric pain caused by Stomach ulcer.
Damp rashes or acne.
Internally or externally for abscesses or other toxic swellings.
Yang sores marked by redness, swelling and pain.
Chronic Yin-type swellings that do not ulcerate or have dark purplish ulcerations that do not close.
Topically for chilblain. (frostbite)
Sore throat with significant swelling or pus.
Heat induced dry cough.
Antidote for a wide variety of toxins.
Relieves palpitations and anxiety.
Strongly clears the throat and Lungs to treat Wind-Heat attacks the Lungs or Fire toxin flaring upwards.
Antidote for poisoning from toxic herbs such as Aconite Fu Zi, Chuan Wu or Crotonis Ba Dou.
As a summertime beverage to prevent Summerheat and Heat rash and to reduce the probability of poisoning from spoiled food.
Dry or restless organ disorder.
Dry organ disorder with Shen disturbance.
Cough and wheezing due to Wind-Heat.
Coughing due to Wind-Cold with sputum.
Cough and wheezing due to Dryness.
Abdominal pain due to Middle Jiao Deficiency Cold.
Diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal pain caused by Damp-Heat.
Burns topically.
Drug poisoning internally.
Leg cramps due to Blood Deficiency.
12g Gan Cao, for herbicide or pesticide poisoning in decoction 3 times daily.
Lead poisoning.
Arsenic poisoning.

notes: It improves digestion.
It has anti-aging properties.
It prevents drying of membranes.
It occurs in about 2/3 of all formulas. It has both an ascending and descending nature.
It treats both Internal and External diseases.
It sensitizes organs to the effects of other herbs.
This herb inhibits the growth of cancer cells.
This herb tonifies in mediating formulas, clears fever in cooling formulas, dispels pathogens in the muscles in diaphoretic formulas and nourishes the Blood and expels toxins in relaxing formulas.
For Wei (atrophy) Syndrome, use Gan Cao alone.
For uncomplicated sores, use alone topically.
For erysipelas, use alone in decoction topically.
For red lesions, with eczema and itching, use alone in decoction topically.
For a mild sore throat, use alone.
When extremely Hot or extremely Cold herbs are used, this herb must be added to mediate the intensity.
When Cold and Hot herbs are used in the same formula, this herb must be included to harmonize the properties.
For food poisoning from beef, use alone as a decoction.
It neutralizes the toxicity of Rx. Aconiti Lateralis Preparata #{ZhiFuZi} Zhi Fu Zi.
It controls the warm property of Rz. Zingiberis #{GanJiang} Gan Jiang to prevent damage to Yin.
It prevents the cold properties of Gypsum Fibrosum #{ShiGao} Shi Gao and Rx. Anemarrhena #{ZhiMu} Zhi Mu from damaging the Stomach.
It reduces the initial peak effect of Rx. et Rz. Rhei #{DaHuang} Da Huang and Natrii Sulfas #{MangXiao} Mang Xiao and prolongs the overall duration of their effects.

It reduces the initial peak effect of Rz. Atractylodis Macrocephalae, #{BaiZhu} Bai Zhu, Rx. Codonopsis #{DangShen} Dang Shen, Rx. Rehmanniae #{ShuDiHuang} Shu Di Huang, and Rx. Angelicae Sinensis #{DangGui} Dang Gui, and prolongs their overall effects.

Both Gan Cao and Maltose #{YiTang} Yi Tang tonify the Qi of the Middle Jiao, moderate urgency and relieve pain. Gan Cao resolves toxicity, but does not nourish Blood. It moistens the Lungs to stop cough but has less fluid generating capability than Yi Tang which generates fluids especially in the Lungs, relieves thirst and nourishes Blood.
Dry-fried Licorice Chao Gan Cao has enhanced warming ability. Dry-frying with bran boosts its ability to harmonize the Stomach.
Honey-prepared Licorice Mi Zhi Gan Cao has increased ability to tonify the Middle, augment the Heart and Spleen and harmonize the properties of other herbs.
Licorice tips Gan Cao Shao are cool in nature, drain Fire and resolve toxicity. They excel in treating Damp-Heat Pouring Downward into the Bladder and causing urethral pain.
It boosts adrenal and pancreatic weaknesses, especially in those with functional blood sugar Deficiency.
Powdered Rx. Glycyrrhizae Gan Cao Fen is considered to be of higher quality than regular Rx. Glycyrrhizae Gan Cao.
